title: BOJ's ETF purchase hits over three-year low in Sept, but unlikely to be tapering
text:
TOKYO (Reuters) - The Bank of Japan’s exchange-traded funds purchase this month hit the lowest level in more than three years, but few market players see it as a sign the central bank is tapering its stock buying.

FILE PHOTO : A security guard walks past in front of the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo, Japan January 23, 2019. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

The BOJ bought 163 billion yen (1.22 billion pounds) worth of Japanese stock ETFs in September, central bank data showed on Monday.

It was the smallest monthly buying after the central bank doubled the buying target to 6 trillion yen per year in July 2016. So far this year, the BOJ has bought 3.6 trillion yen in ETFs, about 20% less than same period last year.

BOJs ETF buying hits the lowest in 3 years: here

The pace of BOJs ETF buying slowing in 2019: here

Nevertheless, market players see few immediate policy implications.

The BOJ's buying fell in September as the BOJ has been sticking to its unwritten, self-imposed rule that it buys ETFs on a day when the Topix index .TOPX falls 0.5% or more in the morning.

In September, the BOJ bought only a little, just because Japanese shares have rallied strongly, with the Topix comfortably outperforming global peers.

Topix climbed 5.0%, compared with 1.2% gain in the U.S. S&P500 .SPX and 3.2% rise in Europe's STOXX600 .

Yet, analysts say the outperformance of Japanese shares was largely due to short-covering by foreign speculators while long-only investors have mostly stayed away, suggesting the market remains vulnerable.

Foreign flows into Japanese stocks: here

One key worry for overseas investors is a hit to the Japanese economy from an imminent consumption tax hike, scheduled on Tuesday.

“It will take time before long-only foreign investors start buying Japanese shares as ‘global cyclical stocks’,” said Masatoshi Kikuchi, chief equity strategist at Mizuho Securities.

“We think they will wait and see how the domestic economy fares after the sales tax hike and whether mid-year earnings reporting season shows a profit turnaround.”

For the past year or so, Japan Inc’s earnings outlook has been constantly deteriorating.

Japan corporate earnings: here

There is likely to be a bumpy road ahead, said Norihiro Fujito, chief investment strategist at Mitsubishi UFJ Morgan Stanley Securities, citing many uncertain factors such as U.S.-China trade talks and U.S. congressional moves to impeach President Donald Trump.

“I think the BOJ is glad to have a plenty of room left to buy ETFs for the Oct-Dec period. The central bank could still end up using the remaining allowance by the year end.”
